title: Edge Coloring
content:
An **n-edge-coloring** assigns a color from Fin n to each edge.

We use `Sym2 V` to represent unordered pairs (edges), so the coloring is automatically symmetric: color({u,v}) is well-defined.

title: Cycle in a Graph
content:
A **cycle** is a list of vertices [v₀, v₁, ..., vₖ₋₁] where:
- Length ≥ 3
- All vertices distinct (Nodup)
- Consecutive vertices are adjacent: G.Adj vᵢ vᵢ₊₁
- The cycle closes: G.Adj vₖ₋₁ v₀

title: Odd Cycle
content:
An **odd cycle** is a cycle with odd length (3, 5, 7, ...).

Odd cycles are the key obstruction to bipartiteness: a graph is bipartite ↔ it has no odd cycles.

title: Monochromatic Cycle
content:
A cycle is **monochromatic in color c** if every edge of the cycle has color c.

This is the structure we're trying to force: a monochromatic odd cycle.

title: Has Monochromatic Odd Cycle
content:
The predicate `HasMonochromaticOddCycleOfLength G coloring m` asserts:

∃ cycle, ∃ color c, cycle is odd AND monochromatic in c AND length ≤ m

This is what f(n) measures: the minimum m that is always forced.

title: Complete Graph K_n
content:
The **complete graph** K_n has all possible edges: every pair of distinct vertices is adjacent.

K_n has n(n-1)/2 edges. The problem studies colorings of K_{2^n+1}.

title: The Function f(n)
content:
**The Key Function:**

f(n) = minimum m such that EVERY n-coloring of K_{2^n+1} has a monochromatic odd cycle of length ≤ m.

This is defined via Nat.find, assuming such m always exists (which follows from the forcing theorem).

title: K_{2^n} Avoids Odd Cycles
content:
**The Doubling Miracle:**

K_{2^n} CAN be n-colored with NO monochromatic odd cycles at all!

Construction: Start with K_2 (1 color). At each step, double the graph and use a new color for cross-edges. Each color class is bipartite, so no odd cycles.
mathContext: This is the key extremal result: 2^n is the threshold.

title: K_{2^n+1} Forces Odd Cycle
content:
**The Forcing Result:**

With n colors on K_{2^n+1}, at least one color must contain an odd cycle.

Why? Each color class avoiding odd cycles is bipartite with ≤ 2^n vertices. But n bipartite graphs on ≤ 2^n vertices can cover at most K_{2^n}!

title: Avoiding C_5
content:
**Short Cycle Avoidance:**

For large enough n, there exists an n-coloring of K_{2^n+1} with no monochromatic pentagon (C_5).

This shows f(n) > 5 for large n — we can avoid the shortest odd cycles.

title: Avoiding C_7
content:
**Heptagon Avoidance:**

For large enough n, monochromatic C_7 can also be avoided.

This further constrains f(n): we know f(n) > 7 for large n.

title: Chung's Question
content:
**Chung (1997):**

Does f(n) → ∞ as n → ∞?

In other words: can arbitrarily long odd cycles be avoided for large enough n?

title: Day-Johnson Lower Bound
content:
**Day-Johnson (2017):**

f(n) ≥ 2^{c√(log n)} for some constant c > 0.

This answered Chung's question affirmatively: f(n) → ∞.

The √(log n) exponent means very slow growth — but still unbounded!

title: f(n) Tends to Infinity
content:
**Chung's Question: ANSWERED YES**

For any M, there exists N such that n ≥ N implies f(n) ≥ M.

The minimum forced odd cycle length grows without bound!

title: Girão-Hunter Upper Bound
Janzer-Yip Upper Bound
The Bounds Gap
content:
**The Exponential Mystery:**

Lower: 2^{c√(log n)} ≈ n^{c'}
Upper: n^{3/2} · 2^{n/2} ≈ exp(n/2)

The gap is EXPONENTIAL! The true behavior of f(n) is completely unknown between these bounds.

title: Cycle Ramsey Numbers
content:
**R(C_k, ..., C_k):**

The r-color Ramsey number for odd cycles C_k is the minimum n such that any r-coloring of K_n has a monochromatic C_k.

For odd k, this grows exponentially in r.

title: Bipartite Characterization
content:
**Classical Result:**

A graph is bipartite ↔ it has no odd cycles.

This is fundamental: avoiding monochromatic odd cycles means each color class is bipartite.

title: Color Classes Are Bipartite
content:
**Key Observation:**

If a color class has no odd cycle, it's bipartite.

So n-coloring K_{2^n+1} without odd cycles requires covering it with n bipartite graphs.

But n bipartite graphs can only cover K_{2^n}, not K_{2^n+1}!

title: The Doubling Construction
content:
**How to n-Color K_{2^n}:**

- Base: K_2 = single edge, 1 color
- Step: Given K_{2^n} with n colors, form K_{2^{n+1}} by taking two copies and connecting all cross-edges with color n+1

Each color class is bipartite (either within a copy, or between copies), so no odd cycles!
